Oh Earth!  how fair thou art!  With life, with mirth,</br>With freshness, and with glory, teemest thou!</br>Say, was the morn that wak'd thee into birth,</br>Than that which sheds its sunbeams on thee now,</br>Of purer radiance, or of rosier glow?</br>The clear, calm sapphire of the cloudless sky,</br>Noon's glance of splendour, gilding the tall brow</br>Of some heav'n-climbing steep; or, these gone by,</br>The mild controul of eve's benignant majesty;

The soft, night-wafted fragrance of the grove,</br>The glitt'ring dews which strew the grassy floor,</br>The tender strain of melancholy love,</br>Which some lone chantress of the woods doth pour,</br>When the loud chorus of the day is o'er;—</br>Oh!  ne'er did Nature offer to the sense</br>Of wayward man a richer, brighter store!</br>How may he rightly prize the gift immense!</br>Earth's loveliness is his, and Heaven's magnificence!

Oh thou, of sparkling eye and jocund breast!</br>Oh thou, whose prime is yet upon the wing!</br>This is thine hour!  And never hour more blest</br>Did Time upon his glancing current bring;</br>Oh, ere it passes, smite the bounding string!</br>Yea, haste to bid the fleeting present hail!</br>And let thy harp around in echoes fling,</br>Of youth, and life, and joy, th' inspiring tale,</br>One wild thanksgiving hymn o'er ocean, hill, and vale!

For thou canst feel and taste, thy glance is strong</br>To mingle with the sunbeam!  'Tis thy hour!</br>Thy heart-pulse dances light to every song;</br>Thy ready fingers pluck the springing flow'r,</br>Just as it opens to the genial show'r</br>Its new-born bloom.  Now, even while ye may,</br>While yet the fibres of your heart have pow'r</br>To keep life's mortal weariness at bay,</br>Wait not to-morrow's dawn!  Be glad, be glad to-day!

Ere mix'd and turbid with the mountain storm,</br>Drink of the stream which sparkles as it flows!</br>Ere eating canker, or the secret worm,</br>Consume the cluster which so brightly glows,</br>Seize thou the bloomy prize.  The summer rose,</br>To deck thy bosom, or thy brow to wreathe,</br>Her fragrance and her blushes doth disclose.</br>Then take her ere she fade, or some rude breath</br>Scatter her lovely leaves thy heedless foot beneath!

The present hour, with all its charms, be thine;</br>All that it gives, all that it promises;</br>For in thy laughing eyes youth's sunbeams shine,</br>And all is real that thy fancy sees!</br>Joy whispers to thee in the morning breeze;</br>With thee she bounds the woodland path along;</br>And will she stay?  Try!  Grasp her ere she flees,</br>Oh!  let her not escape, for thou art young!</br>Youth's pulse is in thy heart, youth's spirit swells thy song.

To each his theme!  For me the present seems</br>A gleamy moment, vague and undefin'd.</br>My fancy wantons 'mid a world of dreams,</br>And Memory's passive vassal is my mind.</br>What is, it wots not, cares not; — for behind,</br>On that which was, are all its glances cast,</br>A region pale, swept by destruction's wind,</br>The native land of dimness and of waste,</br>Of ruins and of graves, — the spectre-peopled Past!

'Tis thus the Spirit of the Desert stays</br>Musing alone!  Behold!  a scatter'd heap</br>Lies pillar'd Tadmor, pride of elder days!</br>Slow o'er the wreck does cold oblivion creep,</br>And sand-fraught whirlwinds o'er the fragments sweep;</br>The grey owl, through the noon-day, undismay'd</br>Pours her dull chant, for all around doth sleep;</br>Her voice alone the silence doth pervade,</br>Where once Longinus thought, and once Zenobia sway'd!

Yet some bold steps still track the wilderness,</br>Led by devotion for the sacred Past;</br>For this they tempt the plain's wild emptiness,</br>The lurking Arab, or the fiery blast,</br>The huge o'erwhelming armies of the waste,</br>Annihilation's legions!  But to gaze</br>A little while on majesty defaced;</br>To sigh and moralize; then go their ways,</br>Revolving in their souls deep thoughts of other days!

Long years gone by, the harp of Selma's halls</br>Gave to the awful Past its solemn strain;</br>It echoed 'mid the dank, deserted walls,</br>Smote by a master hand, — but, ah!  in vain!</br>No chieftain own'd the battle-call again!</br>And he who wak'd it, childless and alone,</br>Blind and bereft, along the silent plain</br>Wander'd, and dream'd of life and glory gone;</br>Or sought his mournful haunt beside the dark-grey stone.

Shut from his sightless orbs, the present scene</br>To him was nothing.  While the sunbeam plays</br>Over the blue bosom of the lake serene,</br>He sate in darkness 'mid the noon-tide blaze!</br>But he had other eyes, whose gifted gaze</br>Illumin'd midnight, peopled solitude;</br>From him did Fate the dim, inglorious days</br>Of present years by kind decree exclude,</br>Nor on his visions might their puny shapes intrude!

The feast of shells — the banquet of the brave</br>Was over, and within the hollow hall</br>The sullen mountain winds did hoarsely rave;</br>There the red thistle and the yarrow tall</br>Wav'd their rank heads; against the mildew'd wall</br>The spear lean'd idle — for the valiant race</br>Had heard the voice which bids the mighty fall!</br>Strong in the battle, — ardent in the chase,</br>But time past o'er their pride, and vacant was their place.

Yet that dark, aged, solitary sire</br>Thrid back the maze of life; he talk'd with those</br>Whose deeds of glory wak'd his harp of fire,</br>Whose radiant morning with his morn arose,</br>Who found, beneath the cromlech's heap, repose!</br>Of them his soul was full!  The very blast,</br>Which raved upon the wint'ry evening's close,</br>Came laden with their forms, sublime and vast,</br>Stern, dark, and terrible — the people of the Past!

Then did the dreary bosom blaze again</br>With flame rekindled, — 'twas the light of song!</br>That light which saves the names of glorious men</br>From time's slow mildew, from oblivion's wrong!</br>Then, borne upon the eddying blast along,</br>The ghosts of heroes gather'd to the sound,</br>Each on his cloud, a dim and dusky throng!</br>Their forms decay beneath the turfy mound!</br>Their names shall die when Time gives o'er his annual round!

That lone lament, that solitary wail,</br>Still floats majestic down the stream of years,</br>And still we listen to the blind old Gael!</br>What is it that the antique lay endears</br>So to our hearts, and cheats us of our tears?</br>What is it wakes such solemn tenderness,</br>Even now, in this our day, in him who hears</br>That rude, wild song, born in the wilderness,</br>Commingling fond regrets with warlike loftiness?

Who has no sigh to sanctify the past,</br>No tear for Memory?  Who can steer his mind</br>Right onward in life's road, nor pause to cast</br>One yearning look on things left far behind?</br>Unenvied be his lot, though he shall find</br>A level causeway and a cloudless day,</br>And travel safe, unskaith'd by Fortune's wind,</br>While we, forlorn, with loitering footstep stray,</br>In vain, to seek the forms which shar'd our earlier way!

Ask those who touch the autumn of their year,</br>The mellow side of their maturity,</br>Why they do halt so oft in their career,</br>Turning their glances tow'rds their eastern sky,</br>Neglectful of the hour which hastens by?</br>Oh!  they will tell you, how, that long ago</br>This world, which now seems fading on their eye,</br>Had skies all glittering bright in golden glow,</br>Then sunshine blaz'd above, and verdure smiled below!

There was a freshness in the ambient gale;</br>There was a sparkle on the river's tide;</br>The emerald's hue o'erspread each dewy vale;</br>Then Flora laugh'd in all her gaudy pride,</br>Her lovely train ten thousand colours dyed!</br>What fragrant hawthorn deck'd the May-bush then!</br>The very milkmaids, as they homeward hied,</br>In those fair evenings, pour'd a blither strain</br>Than e'er comes wafted now along the village lane!

They wonder why so tuneless comes the chime</br>From yon grey spire, to cheer the rustic feast,</br>For they can well recall the distant time,</br>When those old bells, of some strange charm possest,</br>With mirth and joy o'erfill'd the youthful breast!</br>'Tis pleasant yet, to think how merrily</br>They echoed in the heart, ere manhood's guest,</br>Grim care, such irksome music did supply,</br>As dull'd all other sounds, the deep, slow-heaved sigh!

Tornasti Primavera!  But in vain</br>Returnest thou, since they return no more,</br>The little loves which frolick'd in thy train,</br>Youth, and the hopes, which sprang thy steps before,</br>Gay heralds of the jocund spring of yore!</br>The gaudy swarm of bright-wing'd promises,</br>Which erst upon thy flatt'ring breeze did soar,</br>Time brush'd them down, and lent, instead of these,</br>His tarnish'd, way-worn troop, to grace thy pageantries!

Erst when thou camest, how our steps have press'd</br>To snatch the first sweet gem thou didst awake!</br>The violet, lurking in its mossy nest,</br>Or primrose, sprinkling o'er the dewy brake!</br>We spare them now, for sad remembrance' sake,</br>And they shall live their little lives, and stay</br>Till frost, or blight, or worm, their bloom o'ertake;</br>Or, till their fair heads droop in slow decay,</br>They shall not lure us now to linger on our way!

Oh ye, who of the present make your boast!</br>Yours is a trembling bliss!  Ye hold a prize,</br>Which, even as ye look on it, is lost,</br>A shade, which even as ye grasp it, flies!</br>Yea, ere the frail ephemeron, it dies!</br>Ye see it, touch it, speak to it!  And lo!</br>Where is it?  Gone!  Forgotten!  For your eyes</br>Pursue the painted phantoms as they go,</br>Swift following o'er the scenes of life's still varying show!

But that which we are fond to call our own,</br>Is ours, secured by Fate's eternal seal!</br>What chance could do to harm it, chance has done;</br>And time has stol'n, whatever time could steal!</br>The blows which disappointment loves to deal</br>We fear not!  We the heavy cost have paid;</br>Our hearts have felt what hearts bereaved feel,</br>When long-nurs'd hopes in sad succession fade;</br>Now, neither time nor chance our treasure may invade!

We ask no tidings of the passing hour,</br>No longer tempted with its motley ware!</br>Its cup of mingled beverage, sweet and sour,</br>Its little freight of pleasure and of care,</br>Nor wake our fancy, nor our hearts ensnare!</br>Our traffic o'er, the chiding of the blast</br>Threats not our bark, and, tho' the wind be fair,</br>Its swells no sail of ours!  Its anchors cast,</br>Our vessel rides at peace, life's shoals and quicksands past!

The bitter drop is drain'd. The hour has come</br>Which was to come to us!  The sable thread</br>Has cross'd our web!  Yea, we have seen the tomb</br>Close o'er the forms to which our souls were wed!</br>Our sighs are silent now, our tears are shed,</br>Shed in the dust!  Our bosom's secret core</br>Affliction's dart has search'd; and it has bled,</br>As once the heart can bleed, and bleed no more!</br>That is which was to be!  And now the strife is o'er!

Shall apathy's dull twilight overcast</br>Our sky, and dim the remnant of our day?</br>Withering, and overthrown in sorrow's blast,</br>Shall cold indifference on our spirits prey,</br>Till our minds moulder as our frames decay?</br>No!  e'en while on the precious wreck we gaze</br>Of blessings Heaven bestowed, and took away,</br>A voice within us vindicates the ways</br>Of GOD to man, and fills the bruised heart with praise!

Why, what are we, who would our doom evade?</br>If all of Adam born, are born to weep!</br>If every form which of the dust was made,</br>Return, its task fulfill'd, in dust to sleep,</br>Why, what are we, that would our idols keep?</br>Alas!  blind children of the earth are we!</br>Our blessings oft in bitter tears we steep;</br>Our evil we pursue, our good we flee;</br>Eternal Wisdom judge, and question GOD's decree!

The fickle and forgetful may bemoan</br>That time has robb'd them, for the ductile mind</br>Soon closes o'er the past, and all is gone;</br>As travels through the skies the summer wind,</br>Or keel across the wave, and leaves behind</br>A moment's trace, but on the billows glide</br>And the trace fades for ever, none can find</br>What path the vessel took, though deep and wide</br>She cleft the briny waste, as onward she did ride!

And thus it should be!  Some are born to hold,</br>Deep written in their heart, and on their brain,</br>The story of the past, so lively told,</br>That time has journey'd o'er their heads vain,</br>For they do act life's drama o'er again!</br>The present is a shadowy sketch, a dream</br>And all which to the present doth pertain,</br>A form but half defin'd, a cloud, a gleam!</br>The real is, for them, as though it did but seem!

They wander in the same green spots, where erst</br>Their happier fancy led; the common eye</br>Might deem them all alone; but they, who first</br>Did make those paths so pleasant, still are nigh,</br>Arm kindly link'd in arm, for Memory</br>She reeks not of the grave; again she brings</br>The rescued pledges of her victory,</br>E'en from the gulf where cease all mortal things,</br>E'en from the grasp of Fate, the precious prey she wrings!

She leads again, where bold St. Vincent rears,</br>O'er Avon's dusky wave, his forehead grey;</br>The sunshine evenings of long-lapsed years</br>Glow at her bidding, and, as on they stray,</br>The liquid, trembling, melancholy lay</br>Still warbles from the copse.  The virgin-bow'r</br>Spreads o'er the rock its slender tassel'd spray,</br>Its matted foliage, and its feathery flow'r,</br>Even as once it did, in life's benignest hour!

Leaving the murm'ring crowd afar behind,</br>Now blythe across the broomy down they hie,</br>Mingling sweet converse with the healthful wind;</br>Or silent, musing, with enthusiast eye,</br>O'er that wide scene of beauty, till a sigh</br>From each surcharged bosom softly says</br>Why they were silent.  'Tis the heart's reply,</br>Its little meed of unadulterate praise</br>To Him who wrought the pomp, on which they fondly gaze

Thus once it was; and thus by memory's aid</br>Re-living life, thus still it seems to be,</br>Still, as when erst the Sabbath warning bade,</br>Together bending low the duteous knee,</br>Two mingled voices in one pray'r agree!</br>Is this illusion too?  Or may the pray'r</br>A mourning mortal utters, heav'nward flee?</br>May they, whose earth still clings about them, dare</br>Aspire the holy song an Angel sings to share?

A Harp there was, — 'tis mute and stringless now,</br>And cold the hand which smote its tuneful chord!</br>Sweet flow'd the strain, which never more shall flow,</br>And sweeter, sweeter still, a voice which pour'd</br>Full many a note divine and treasur'd word,</br>The heart's own music!  Must it speak no more?</br>Oh yet!  by faithful memory restored,</br>There are who hear it, — in whose bosom's core</br>It speaks, and still shall speak, till life and sense be o'er!

Earth has no sound so pleasant as that still,</br>Soft, mournful, cherish'd voice of other years!</br>It comes o'er the cold breast with kindly thrill,</br>And opes the fountain of assuaging tears!</br>And who, such sad and solemn sound that hears</br>Has ear for aught beside?  "Awake," it cries,</br>The laden spirit it uplifts and cheers—</br>"Awake!  and think how brief the pathway lies,</br>Time's journey to fulfil, between ye and the skies!"

A little while, — and they who fondly muse</br>On things which were, and are not, even they</br>Shall be like that their wayward thought pursues,</br>A thing which was, and is not!  Yesterday</br>They wept, they smil'd, they felt the heart-pulse play;</br>They shrank and shudder'd in the chilling blast,</br>Or bask'd exulting in the genial ray,</br>Unconscious they, how they were tending fast</br>There, whence no foot returns, the region of the Past!

And be it so!  For, them who went before,</br>The weary soul is panting to o'ertake;</br>Fain would it spread its wings, and heav'nward soar,</br>And fain to earth each earthy burthen shake;</br>For the world's cumbrous fetter sorrow brake,—</br>That magic fetter, that entangling tie,</br>Which makes man deem it bitter to forsake</br>The varying light of time's capricious sky</br>For that unclouded day which fills Eternity!</br>
